bBRTHx-w6.memHandModelNotes: The patch model is intended to select open habitat types of 1 ha or more but not larger than a continuous patch with a 250 m radius; and also selects forest types 60m into the forest edge.  Shrubby habitats should have no size limit and so no buffer in length becauseThrashers can use extensive shrubby areas to breed.

references.B48BEN01NAUS: Bent, A.C. 1948. Life histories of North American nuthatches, wrens, thrashers, and their allies. U.S. National Museum Bulletin 195. Washington, D.C.
references.B96KAU01NCGP: Kaufman K. 1996. Lives of North American Birds. Boston, New York: Houghton Mifflin Company.
references.B83AOU01USGP: American Ornithologists' Union (AOU). 1983. Check-list of North American Birds, 6th edition. Allen Press, Inc., Lawrence, Kansas. 877 pp.
references.A86MUR01NAUS: Murphy, M. T., and R. C. Fleischer. 1986. Body size, nest predation, and reproductive patterns in brown thrashers and other mimids. Condor 88:446-455.
references.A76FOR01SEGP: Forman, R. T. T., A. E. Galli, and C. F. Leck. 1976. Forest size and avian diversity in new jersey woodlots with some land use implications. Oecologia.
references.B75HAR01HQUS: Harrison, H.H. 1975. A field guide to bird's nests in the U.S. east of the Mississippi River. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston, Massachusetts. 257 p.
references.A81KER01NAUS: Kerlinger, P., and C. Doremus. 1981. Habitat disturbance and the decline of dominant avian species in pine barrens of the northeastern United States. American Birds 35:16-20.
references.B79HAR01NAUS: Harrison, H.H. 1979. A field guide to western birds' nests. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston. 279 pp.
references.A84SIB01NAUS: Sibley, C.G., and J.E. Ahlquist. 1984. The relationshipsof the starlings (Stunidae:Stunini) and the mockingbirds (Sturnidae:Mimini). Auk 101:230-243.
references.B00CAV01SEGP: Cavitt, J. F., and C. A. Haas. 2000. Brown Thrasher (Toxostoma rufum). In The Birds of North America, No. 557 (A. Poole and F. Gill, eds.). The Birds of North America, Inc., Philadelphia, PA.
references.B92HAM01NAUS: Hamel, P. B. 1992. The land manager's guide to the birds of the south. The Nature Conservancy, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. 367 pp + several appendices.
references.B58BUR01NAUS: Burleigh, T. D. 1958. Georgia birds. Univ. Oklahoma Press, Norman. 746 pp.
references.B88EHR01NAUS: Ehrlich, P.R., D.S. Dobkin, and D. Wheye. 1988. The birder's handbook:a field guide to the natural history of North American birds. Simon and Shuster, Inc., New York. xxx + 785 pp.
references.B80TER01NAUS: Terres, J.K. 1980. The Audubon Society encyclopedia of North American birds. Alfred A. Knopf, New York.
references.B78HAR01NAUS: Harrison, C. 1978. A field guide to the nests, eggs and nestlings of North American birds. Collins, Cleveland, Ohio.
references.B80POT01NAUS: Potter, E. F., J. F. Parnell, and R. P. Teulings. 1980. Birds of the Carolinas. Univ. North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill. 408 pp.
